All Reviews

  1. Great eye gel! Very effective!
  2. no visable results. will not buy again
  3. After using this for months, I wasn't completely whether if it was making a difference. But now, I have no doubt it works! Because...recently, I went about 2 weeks without using it. (I ran out of it, and wasn't able to get around to reordering it for about 2 weeks.) In that two weeks that I stopped using it, I noticed a gradual but significant increase in the appearance of the wrinkles around my eyes, as well as increased dryness. Now that I'm using the gel again, I have seen a significant decrease in the appearance of the wrinkles around my eyes. It does not completely remove the wrinkles, of course (this ain't a miracle drug), but for me at least, it truly reduces the visibility of the wrinkles around my eyes--as long as I keep using it.
  4. Great product. Will buy again.

  9. This is the only eye moisturizer I've ever used that seems to make a difference. The puffiness and dark circles under my eyes do seem to be improving after a month's use. It comes in a .5 fl. oz bottle, which was dismaying to me at first. But no problem because, as with all Oz products, only a very small amount is needed at a time. Be careful not to pump the bottle too hard or you'll release more gel than needed.<br /><br />In the morning, I've been washing with the Vitamin C cleanser, then applying the Vitamin C serum. Then I pat on the eye gel and finish with the Sea Infused Herbal Moisturizer. In the evenings, I wash with the same cleanser and just apply the serum and eye gel. I'm 60, have dry skin, and absolutely love the results I'm seeing.

I used this product religiously day and night for two months because I wanted to be fair and give it an adequate amount of time to see results. I did not realize that all the OZ products have a 30 day limit on their guarantee. I saw absolutely no improvement. I finally decided this was ridiculous and decided to ask for my money back since they give a 100% guarantee. Doesn't work that way. I didn't read the small print. After 30 days the guarantee is no longer valid and you cannot return the product or get your money back. The company must be inferring that you should see results before 30 days is up. If you don't, be sure to contact the company, because results are not forthcoming.

I have sensitive skin and this does not irritate my skin in any way. I will update my review over time once I have a few weeks of use but so far this is doing what it says it does. I also suggest comparing the ingredients list and going with the best priced brand of this type of eye gels.<br /><br />5 stars<br /><br />I was provided a sample for review and I do not promise a good rating in return, nor am I affiliated with this company or compensated in any way. I am just a regular Amazon customer who shops a lot on Amazon.
  281. wonderful will buy again
  282. I purchased this item on September 4th, 2014. It has now been exactly three months. I've been using it diligently every night, as well as the majority of mornings. That being said, I can't really tell you yet if the product will show any results in the future. Maybe it is too soon to tell. (If it does, I'll provide an update!) But based upon this time span of usage, I've found no improvements whatsoever. I am already half way through the product. Here's hoping that in another three months or so that I have till the bottle is finished, there will be some result. I have puffy dark eye circles, as well as wrinkles on the upper eyelid and lower lash line area. I'd been expecting to find some improvement at least on reducing the puffiness or preventing further minute wrinkles, but unfortunately there have been no such results. I chose to buy this item because it is highly rated and many people seem to have benefited from OZ Naturals' eye gel. I'm a bit disappointed that it hasn't worked with me, and am not sure if I will buy again. If anything, it at least acts in place of a moisturizer appropriate for the delicate skin around the eye. I do love that the product won't be sticky or heavy on your eyes, and does leave a smooth touch after applying. If you're sensitive to most products, maybe be careful about putting it too close to your eye or near the waterline. It tends to burn just a little bit if it's too close, and makes my water line a bit red, one of the reasons why I decided not to put it on too often during the mornings. The burning sensation is only very faint when put around the lower lash line area. I'm personally not sensitive to products, having fared alright with other intense skin products. Another reason why I refrain from applying it is when I'm applying makeup. I've found that using the product, and after some minutes of waiting, then applying makeup, will produce something like dandruff or tiny dead skin but isn't either of these things, and I find it abit annoying to have to brush the tiny white particles away after applying my makeup. If you're someone skeptical about how effective products are, than maybe don't put too much hope on this product. Still, I suggest giving it a try and seeing if it does work on you! It seems to have worked on many others! I don't think the price is that bad either, so it's worth a try. Update: I completed the entire bottle, down to the very last drops. There weren't any noticeable differences during usage, although I believe it was moisturizing for my eye area. If you're looking for just a moisturizer, I would recommend this product. However, if you're looking to reduce black eye circles, puffiness, and small wrinkles, this may not be for you. I will not be purchasing this product again, but I do not regret purchasing it to try it out. I have yet to find an effective product for my eye area, and this product didn't make the bottom of the list of tried products, so there's that!

But I can say that its moisturizing capability is very good, and does seem to make wrinkles around the eyes slightly less deep.

  555. sodium benzoate: http://www.naturalnews.com/033726_sodium_benzoate_cancer.html<br />Parkinson's, neuro-degenerative diseases, and premature aging have all been attributed to this infamous preservative.<br />Sources:<br />http://www.spafromscratch.com/sodium-benzoate-dangers/<br />to be fair, sodium benzoate is supposed to stop mold/fungus: http://www.ei-resource.org/forum/general-ei-discussion/178-sodium-benzoate-and-mitochondrial-dna-damage/<br /><br />http://www.pureinsight.org/node/4649 :The Hyperactive Children's Support Group of Great Britain takes exception to that and recommends the voidance of both sodium benzoate and benzoic acid. Piper considers tests done by the FDA &#34;out of date.&#34;<br /><br />http://www.inchem.org/documents/cicads/cicads/cicad26.htm#SubSectionNumber:11.1.1 :In a short-term inhalation study with rats exposed to benzoic acid (0, 25, 250, or 1200 mg dust aerosol/m3; 6 h per day, 5 days per week, over 4 weeks), indications of fibrosis in the lung were seen even at the lowest concentration. The number of these microscopic lesions was higher in treated animals than in controls, but there was no clear dose dependency for this effect. Therefore, a no-observed-(adverse-)effect concentration (NO(A)EC) value cannot be derived. Long-term inhalation studies with benzoic acid or sodium benzoate were not identified.<br /><br />http://www.topformsecrets.com/2011/03/sodium-benzoate-in-club-soda-is.html :Just learned today that the sodium benzoate added as a preservative to many foods (including soft drinks and club soda) is carcinogenic. It forms benzene in the presence of vitamin C and E, or in an acidic environment—and benzene is a strong carcinogen. The manufacturers of sodium benzoate should be stopped from adding this poisin to soft drinks. There is evidence that benzene can also damage mitochondria (the powerhouse of cells), cause cirrhosis of the liver, and neurodegenerative disease, including Parkinson's. (Photo Professor Peter Piper, University of Sheffield)

I’m not so sure about the puffiness/black circles, but I assume it does well for that too.<br /><br />It’s formulated for applying to the thin skin near your eyes, so it’s not irritable at all–which is a bonus for someone like me with sensitive eyes. Instead, there’s a very slight cooling sensation as the gel dries. You only need a thin layer every night, so despite the small size of the bottle, it’s been lasting me quite a while.<br /><br />As a side note, I’ve found it best to use it during the night, right before sleeping, as that gives the eye cream plenty of time to work its magic. I’ve been using it for two weeks, and I’ll keep this review updated as I use it longer. Overall though, this eye cream contains some powerful ingredients, but this does NOT mean that it would work for everyone, since everyone’s skins are different.   781. I am going to update this review as I use this product. So, I'll give my initial impression now, come back in 2 weeks, then do a 30 day review.<br /><br />A little about myself and my skin: I am 25, I work at a law firm and I'm attending law school at night, and I've got a killer commute (100+ miles in a car 4 days a week). I imbibe a fair amount of caffeine, have a lot of stress and don't get nearly enough sleep, so I have some pretty defined dark circles. I have sensitive, acne-prone and very combination skin-- think oil slick forehead and nose, barren desert lowest third of my cheeks/jawline. I came across this product looking for some help with the dark circles and to get started on a good, anti-aging/wrinkle preventing regime that would not cause more acne or aggravate my sensitive skin.<br /><br />Initial impression: I like it!<br /><br />The texture of the product is definitely gel like, so don't let the &#34;eye cream&#34; in the product name confuse you. It's a cloudy clear, well, hair-gel like substance. A little goes a long way! I pumped out a small pea-like amount and it was too much. I dabbed the product on my under eyes, my browbones, the outer corners (where the &#34;crows feet&#34; start forming) and then dabbed the remaining product in a second layer over the same areas. It stung a teensy bit where I have some weird dry patches near my eyebrows, but it didn't irritate my skin anywhere else.. so I will chalk that up to the dry patches. I'm not sure I would use this during the day (unless I was going to be home or go without makeup) as it does leave a sort of film like another reviewer mentioned.

I liked seeing the amount so I knew when to reorder. I now run out and then have to wait for a new delivery. The bottle aside, the product itself really works. This feels and smells like a cucumber eye spa treatment. You can feel your skin tightening and it helps reduce my puffy eyes and crows feet. You really don't need to use that much, a tiny pearl size amount is enough. I give it about 15 minutes to completely dry. I'm using this product with the OZ hyaluronic serum and the retinal moisturizer. I used to buy Roc retinal but I gave their retinal a try and it seems to work just as well and you get much more.
  788. I received this from a promtion website Snagshout. I did not expect such a nice quality eye gel. It makes my skin smooth. It left no sticky residue either like a lot of other gels. Was very glad to be able to try it before I buy it.

  907. I have been using this product (provided to me for review) for a couple of weeks. Do I see miraculous changes? No. Did I expect to see such from any beauty product? No.<br /><br />My approach to skincare is rather scattershot, perhaps because there is no solid science here, only marketing claims; I'm not willing to spend hundreds of dollars on fanciful advertising, nor am I willing to experiment with potentially toxic chemicals. So, I aim for products that<br /><br />1. Don't contain chemicals considered hazardous or unhealthful on the Environmental Working Group's Skin Deep database (Yes, I know it's not the last word on certain ingredients, but for now it's the best I have)<br />2. Do contain ingredients that make some bit of scientific sense (such as Vitamin C, Vitamin E, hyaluronic acid, etc.)<br />3. Feel good on the skin<br />4. Have no annoying odors<br />5. Are easy to apply<br />6. Are efficiently designed, so as not to take up inordinate space in my medicine chest<br />7. At least fool me into seeing some benefit on my inevitably aging skin<br /><br />I recently received three OZ Naturals products for trial, and I'm pretty happy with all three, based on the criteria above: this Vitamin C serum, the Super Youth Eye Gel, and the Hyaluronic acid.<br /><br />Of the three, the eye gel might my least favorite, but only because I prefer a rich emollient eye cream; this gel dries quickly and feels dry. Maybe it's doing what it's supposed to, but for those who are looking for more moisture, this might not fit the bill. To hedge my bets, I apply it, let it dry, and then apply a moisturizer.

I am not putting a lot of the gel on my entire face and around the eyes, a little goes along way and I tap and lightly massage the product into my face until the tackiness disappears and I know its been absorbed. Here's my results - I am flabbergasted with the results I am seeing in such a short period of time... or rather I am astonished with the results I am seeing period. The dark circles have diminished considerably. For me they are still there but ever so lightly. The puffiness goes away completely. I keep it in the refrigerator for a cooling sensation after a warm shower or bath.<br /><br />It has a fresh vegetal smell dominated by cucumber and a translucent white color and only a slight viscosity. It is almost instantly absorbed when applied.<br /><br />It contains mostly botanical and organic ingredients that moisturize, soften, and protect the outer layer of the skin, such as aloe, glycerin and jojoba oil, plus ingredients like hyaluronic acid and vitamin E that penetrate it to support skin health and structure on a cellular level. Regular use will help improve the appearance of fine wrinkles caused by age and damage from sunlight.<br /><br />The 0.5 oz. (15 ml) bottle is opaque to protect the contents from light and it has a convenient pump top that dispenses just a drop as well as a protective cap.<br /><br />Ingredients: Organic aloe, Matrixyl 3000, palmitoyl tripeptide-3, kosher vegetable glycerin, plant stem cells, cucumber hydrosol, organic jojoba oil, botanical hyaluronic acid, MSM, hydroxyethyl cellulose, carrageenan gum, silk amino acid blend (sodium L-pyrrolidone carboxylate, sodium lactate, L-arginine, L-aspartic acid, L-pyrrolidonecarboxylic acid, glycine, L-alanine, L-serine, L-valine, L-proline, L-threonine, L-isoleucine, L-histidine, L-phenylalanine), wildcrafted periwinkle, organic licorice, wildcrafted eye bright, wildcrafted reishi, organic gotu kola, frankincense, vitamin E, sodium benzoate, potassium sorbate, ethylhexyglycerin.<br /><br />OZ Naturals provided eye gel for evaluation and review.

  1264. When I received an invitation to try some products from the OZ Naturals range, I did my usual research and read up about the brand and its products before accepting. I only have one face and my skin has become increasingly sensitive with age, so I have to be very careful about the stuff I put on it. I was intrigued by the clearly scientific approach, the full disclosure of ingredients and the cruelty-free statement. Also the active ingredients are exactly those I have so far found most effective: hyaluronic acid, peptide complex, vitamin E and some plant-based extracts. Plant stem cells and Matrixyl 3000 were new to me but sounded promising. As usual, when testing skin care, I started using this eye gel by itself, discontinuing my previous eye cream, and hoping for the best, because I do have problems with dark circles, lines and puffiness.<br /><br />This eye product is an almost clear, medium-textured gel which disappears into my skin after a very short massage, leaving a perfect basis for make-up. That, in itself, is rare in my experience. Usually eye-specific preparations are either too light and almost drying, or else they tend to leave a greasy residue which surfaces later through foundation or primer. This gel can be applied several times a day, so I used it first thing in the morning after washing my face and at night after cleansing, in combination with a serum (also by OZ Naturals) and topped by a night cream.<br /><br />Now, does it work? The maker suggests that full results can be seen after 60 days of regular use, so I am hopeful for even more, but so far (after three weeks) I can see a definite improvement. My dark circles are much less evident, my skin is smoother and I can use a bit of concealer without ending up with a caked and lined mess. Also my eyelids are firmer and less puffy and I like the fact that I can apply this gel to the top of my eye, most products are not recommended for the eyelids.<br /><br />I could see a visible difference, especially when looking at photos taken a month ago, but I got the clearest confirmation the other day, when I happened to look at my face mid-afternoon and was dismayed to see that a hint of bags had returned under my eyes. And then I remembered: a house guest had disrupted my routine and I had forgotten to put the gel on for two days! I quickly remedied and was able to reapply foundation without the raccoon-eye look that some other gels produce.<br /><br />The bottle holds ½ fluid ounce or 15 ml of gel, and I have no idea how much there is left, but the pump dispenser works extremely well and it seems I only need a tiny amount each time so it appears to be very good value for money as well. In any case, this is a product I would not want to be without, so I will be replacing it once it runs out. As far as eye creams go, it's the best specific product I have ever tried and absolutely gentle and non-irritating in this very sensitive area.<br /><br />NB: I received this item for free with a request to fully test and evaluate it. As usual, my review reflects my own views and experience with the product and was in no way influenced by the manufacturer.ence, especially when looking at photos taken a month ago, but I got the clearest confirmation the other day, when I happened to look at my face mid-afternoon and was dismayed to see that a hint of bags had returned under my eyes. And then I remembered: a house guest had disrupted my routine and I had forgotten to put the gel on for two days! I quickly remedied and was able to reapply foundation without the raccoon-eye look that some other gels produce.<br /><br />The bottle holds ½ fluid ounce or 15 ml of gel, and I have no idea how much there is left, but the pump dispenser works extremely well and it seems I only need a tiny amount each time so it appears to be very good value for money as well. In any case, this is a product I would not want to be without, so I will be replacing it once it runs out. As far as eye creams go, it's the best specific product I have ever tried and absolutely gentle and non-irritating in this very sensitive area.<br /><br />NB: I received this item for free with a request to fully test and evaluate it. As usual, my review reflects my own views and experience with the product and was in no way influenced by the manufacturer.
  1265. OZ Naturals makes a great eye gel. This has a perfect weight to it. It feels light and a little slippery going on and absorbs quickly and easily. I was surprised by how this feels cooling even when it is going on.<br /><br />I spend a lot of time reading every day, sometimes painfully small print, and my eyes often look tired at the end of the day. Lately, I have also noticed noticeable bags under my eyes. It has been a terrible development. After a few weeks of using this eye gel, the bags under my eyes are less noticeable.<br /><br />Eye care is so tricky because I don’t like gloppy stuff. Other beneficial ingredients in this product are: various amino acids which are the building blocks of proteins and therefore will assist in repairing tissue and smooth the skin. Vitamin E is included which is an antioxidant.
